instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01827: What is 820-01827? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.CHGR_CSO_P: What is CHGR_CSO_P? CHGR_CSO_P is one of the current sense lines for the battery. Resistance between CHGR_CSO_P and CHGR_CSO_N should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 2.2 ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
Hello,

I got this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, sudden death, no 19V on all port.

I've disconnect battery and charger and focus on big coil value to ground (in blue on the pics).

I will user  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  in boardview

Thanks
Sam

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>?
If any missing, post diode mode to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
thanks. I get nothing on both.

Diode mode to ground = 0.25

USB-C chip not talking to charger ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
You can't get same reading on both rails.
Please, post accurate information.

Do you get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
Sorry, 0.331 on  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 

Yes, I get 5.16V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
So you get 0.25 at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

Post basic <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltage; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>EN_MVR</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CBC_ON</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.29V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  Diode Mode = 0.03

Boardview is not exactly same but I beleive <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> should be this guy "338s00267-a0"? 
Everything on the pics is at 0V.

threads.message: according to boardview this could be <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, looks different compare to what I watch on video.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message: Could be this one? What I can say is both have 0 V on all components on the pics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
You have T2 machine, where <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> is used; very small BGA chip; on the other board's side.

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  Diode Mode = 0.03"
No reason to connect power anymore; need to find the culprit first.
Check diode mode to ground on all big coils; see if any has similar value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message: Thanks. Ok, no 0.03 on big coil. I am looking for <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> on verso... not found yet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message: Check this...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message: thanks. There's a few caps and resistor to GND.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message: Compare with 01041/1814 schematic/boardview to identify these components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message: Thanks. So shorted to GND by <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Need to replace that chip. Anything else to test before ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
Why do you think the culprit is <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>???

Check resistance to ground at CPU big coils (all of them).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
I did Big coils. Need to do medium one (in blue) ?

I said <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> as those components are all to GND trough <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
Yeah, that ones too; even L9080/580 for SSD.
Look at schematic and check ANY coil which is part of a secondary power supply connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

I'm pretty sure <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is not the culprit here.
As per schematic, the marked point is connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
I've measure all. You think I should find a coil open ?

What do you mean by "the marked point is connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>" ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
You've marked <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSO_P</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; it is connected to F7000/1, as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> too.

Check direct between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and coils marked with 0.02.
You should get 0.05, or 0.01; let us know.

I can't read the values on the SSD coils...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to the three big coils(0.02) = 0.05
I've added SSD pics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
That means the short don't come from a secondary power supply.
Just in case, did you check L3500 and L9580 too?
Are placed on the other side of the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
Thanks

L3500 to GND = 0.442
L3500 to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.468

[B]L9580 to GND = 0.0[/B]
L9580 to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.003

L9581 same as L9580

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
OK, the short is now found; it is <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>.
Remove <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> and check diode mode to ground at L9580/81 again.
If still short there, at least one NAND chip is fried.

The short from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground, will of course disapper.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message: Sorry for the delay. Ok, NAND is fried. Can Macbook work with one NAND if I remove the faulty one ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message:
NO.
In fact, you may need to replace all of them; from donor board, in same position.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message: Thank you for all your help. So I gave up and reassembled the Mac today. I did a little test before preparing the package. I see it's taking from 0.11 to 1.06 amp when I press the power button. So I tried to put it in DFU, that works. I tried "revive" but it failed with  "the operation couldn't be completed (AMRetoreErrrorDomain error 6 - Failed to handle message type StatusMsg (Operation failed) ... Is it worth try with Apple GSX server ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Sudden death - 19V missing all USB-C port
threads.message: I did more test and it's definitely better than before.
